{"data": {"production":{"id":"pariah","production_title":"Pariah","production_status":3,"production_desc":"

A world premiere at the 2011 Sundance Film Festival, the contemporary drama Pariah<\/em> is the feature-length expansion of writer\/director Dee Rees’ award-winning 2007 short film Pariah<\/em><\/strong>. Spike Lee is among the feature’s executive producers. At Sundance, cinematographer Bradford Young was honored with the [U.S. Dramatic Competition] Excellence in Cinematography Award.<\/p>

Adepero Oduye, who had earlier starred in the short film, portrays Alike (pronounced ah-lee-kay<\/em>), a 17-year-old African-American woman who lives with her parents Audrey and Arthur (Kim Wayans and Charles Parnell) and younger sister Sharonda (Sahra Mellesse) in Brooklyn’s Fort Greene neighborhood. She has a flair for poetry, and is a good student at her local high school.<\/p>

Alike is quietly but firmly embracing her identity as a lesbian. With the sometimes boisterous support of her best friend, out lesbian Laura (Pernell Walker), Alike is especially eager to find a girlfriend. At home, her parents’ marriage is strained and there is further tension in the household whenever Alike’s development becomes a topic of discussion. Pressed by her mother into making the acquaintance of a colleague’s daughter, Bina (Aasha Davis), Alike finds Bina to be unexpectedly refreshing to socialize with.<\/p>

Wondering how much she can confide in her family, Alike strives to get through adolescence with grace, humor, and tenacity – sometimes succeeding, sometimes not, but always moving forward.<\/p>","in_theaters":"
